text: Hey all, I am putting the finishing touches on my JuliaCon proposal and am a bit concerned. I know the proposal has a 5000 character limit. My proposal is sitting at around 3400 characters. I have compared it against the rubric that JuliaCon puts out on what is a strong proposal. I feel like I have addressed each one of those points (e.g. clarity, diversity, community contribution, etc.). Are there common parts that folks leave out of their proposal or could speak more to that often ends up getting their proposal nixed from JuliaCon? I am trying to think if I have not addressed any important blind spots.

text: The most important criterion that the reviewers look for is "is this interesting to the JuliaCon audience".  So if you answer the question "why should someone care about this work", then you are golden. Everything else is not that important.

elements.text: The most important criterion that the reviewers look for is "is this interesting to the JuliaCon audience".  So if you answer the question "why should someone care about this work", then you are golden. Everything else is not that important.

text: Note that the JuliaCon audience is very diverse, so its not necessary that everyone will be interested in what you do. But there should be some particular reason why some particular group of people will be interested in your work. If that comes across in your proposal, you are good.
